quiz.title: Calculus Limits Quiz 1
quiz.subtitle: Intermediate Value Theorem — Basic Applications (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Calculus

questions.question: The Intermediate Value Theorem applies to functions that are:
questions.explanation: IVT requires continuity on a closed interval [a,b].

questions.question: If f(x) is continuous on [1,3] with f(1)=2 and f(3)=5, the IVT guarantees that f(x) takes which value?
questions.explanation: IVT guarantees f takes every value between f(1)=2 and f(3)=5.

questions.question: For f(x)=x² on [1,2], the IVT guarantees a root exists:
questions.explanation: f(1)=1>0, f(2)=4>0 - same sign, so IVT doesn't guarantee a root.

questions.question: If f is continuous on [0,4] with f(0)=-3 and f(4)=5, IVT guarantees a root exists because:
options: f(0) and f(4) have opposite signs
questions.explanation: f(0)<0 and f(4)>0, so by IVT there exists c in (0,4) with f(c)=0.

questions.question: Which function on [0,2] satisfies IVT conditions to guarantee a root?
questions.explanation: f(0)=-1<0, f(2)=3>0, continuous on [0,2] - satisfies IVT conditions.

questions.question: The IVT can be used to prove that the equation x³+x-1=0 has a solution:
questions.explanation: f(0)=-1<0, f(1)=1>0, continuous everywhere - root in (0,1).

questions.question: If f is continuous on [a,b] and k is between f(a) and f(b), IVT guarantees:
options: At least one c with f(c)=k
At most one c with f(c)=k
questions.explanation: IVT guarantees existence of at least one such c, not uniqueness.

questions.question: Which condition is NOT required for IVT?
options: f(a) and f(b) have opposite signs
questions.explanation: Opposite signs are only needed for root existence; IVT works for any k between f(a) and f(b).

questions.question: For f(x)=cos(x) on [0,π], IVT guarantees that f(x) takes the value:
questions.explanation: f(0)=1, f(π)=-1, so IVT guarantees all values between -1 and 1, including 0.5.

questions.question: The equation x⁵-3x+1=0 must have a root in:
If f is continuous on [1,5] with f(1)=10 and f(5)=20, IVT guarantees that f(x)=15:
questions.explanation: 15 is between 10 and 20, so IVT guarantees at least one c in (1,5) with f(c)=15.

questions.question: Which function violates IVT conditions on [0,2]?
questions.explanation: f(x)=1/(x-1) is discontinuous at x=1 in [0,2], so IVT doesn't apply.

questions.question: The IVT can be used to show that a continuous function on [0,1] with f(0)=0 and f(1)=1 must:
questions.explanation: 0.5 is between f(0)=0 and f(1)=1, so IVT guarantees f(c)=0.5 for some c.

questions.question: For f(x)=x³-4x on [-2,2], IVT guarantees a root exists because:
questions.explanation: f(-2)=-8<0, f(2)=8>0, continuous - guarantees root in (-2,2).

questions.question: If f is continuous on [a,b] and f(a)·f(b)<0, IVT guarantees:
questions.explanation: f(a)·f(b)<0 means opposite signs, so IVT guarantees a root in (a,b).

questions.question: The equation eˣ=2-x has a solution in:
questions.explanation: Let f(x)=eˣ+x-2. f(0)=-1<0, f(1)=e-1>0, continuous - root in (0,1).

questions.question: IVT guarantees that a continuous function on [0,10] taking values -5 and 10 must take:
questions.explanation: IVT guarantees all intermediate values between -5 and 10 are attained.

questions.question: Which statement about IVT is FALSE?
questions.explanation: IVT requires a closed interval [a,b], not an open interval.

questions.question: For f(x)=x⁴-2x² on [-2,2], IVT guarantees that f(x)=-1:
questions.explanation: f(-2)=8, f(0)=0, f(2)=8. -1 is between f(0)=0 and f(±1)=-1? Wait, f(±1)=-1 exactly. But IVT guarantees at least one solution since -1 is between min and max values.

questions.question: The IVT is most useful for proving:
questions.explanation: IVT is primarily used to prove existence of solutions to equations f(x)=k.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand the Intermediate Value Theorem.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! You grasp the key concepts and applications of IVT.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress! Review the conditions and applications of IVT.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on understanding: continuity + closed interval + k between endpoints = solution exists.
